question: Describe Kekulé's model of the bonding in benzene

socraticPrompts: How many carbon atoms are there?
Are there single or double bonds?
keypoints.partial: A __ng of _ car___ atoms ___ned by _____nate sin___ and ___ble bonds
keypoints.answer: A ring of 6 carbon atoms joined by alternate single and double bonds.

socraticPrompts: What is the connection with bromine?
keypoints.partial: Benzene is not very ___active (will not _____ with ___mine under stan____ cond_______) though to two _____ of the molecule in rapid equi_______ were suggested
keypoints.answer: Benzene is not very reactive (will not react with bromine under standard conditions) though so two forms of the molecule in rapid equilibrium were suggested.

socraticPrompts: What was suggested to help explain the reactivity?
keypoints.answer: It was hypothesised that the bromine molecule could not be attracted to the double bond before the structure changed.

socraticPrompts: Why does it seem that the model is incorrect?
How do single bonds and double bonds differ?
keypoints.answer: C-C single bonds and C=C double bonds have different lengths.

socraticPrompts: What do X-ray studies show about the bond lengths?
keypoints.answer: X-ray studies of benzene show that all 6 of the carbon-carbon bond lengths are the same.
This does not fit with Kekulé's model.
